div1.ab: Minister OF THE NAVY AND THE COLONIES
On the subject of Mr. May proposed by the Consul of the United States to the Navy to fill in the Reunion the functions of Consular Agent.
div1.p:
Mister Minister,
I have the honor of accusing with reception Your Excellence of his dispatch from June 21st of last confirming the decision by which I had refused to Mr. Georges Jenkins May, the provisory authorization to exercise the functions of Consular Agent of the United States in the Reunion.
Your Excellence does me the honor of demanding from me at the same time the information on Mr. May, for the case where his government would desire
div1.ab: To HIs Excellence the Minister of the Navy and the Colonies.
div1.p: would desire to accredit it. I already had the occasion to transmit to Your Excellence, by my confidential letter on the 11th of April, those that were sent to me and that were far from being favorable. Mr. Consul of France in Maurice confirmed to me, since, the substance, but without giving me details. He would certainly be more explicit toward the Department of Foreign Affairs, if he was written to by this Department.
Whatever it be, I can signal to Your Excellence the facts that are passed to St. Denis and that demonstrate how little Mr. May merits

merits the consideration of the authority firstly, he put a certain ostentation to brave the refusal of authorization that I had notified him of and I had to officially call him back with the confidence that this time, he would be held responsable. I deceive myself because, despite these referred refusals, he committed two times public act of Consul, in requiring public force to stop and imprison a seaman of English origin embarked on an American vessel, and who was at the state of desertation- put immediately in liberty by my orders, this seaman, stopped once more, was on the requisition of Mr. May affirming the police force His
His title of American Consul, renewed with intense force to his rim.
The Consul of His Majesty Britanic, informed of this fact, must grasp his Government.

As for the local administration, it deferred, without delay, Mr. May to the justice. A judiciary instruction was commenced and he will be rendered guilty to the Department by a special report. As of now, I do not hesitate to say that, even by these facts, Mr. May would not know the be accredited as Consular agent in the Reunion.
I am with the most profound respect, Mister Minister, of Your Excellence the very obediant servant. The Governor. S De
